citations.narrative:
There is an accumulation of old food waste stuck in the wire mesh at the front of the owl monkey enclosures. These
enclosures also have a build up a dark brown material on the perches and food stations.
Not maintaining appropriate levels of cleanliness in areas where non-human primates come in contact can result in an
excessive build-up of materials, which can increase the disease risk for the animals contained within. Per the regulations,
hard surfaces with which nonhuman primates come in contact must be spot-cleaned daily and sanitized in accordance
with § 3.84 of this subpart to prevent accumulation of excreta or disease hazards. If the species scent mark, the surfaces
must be sanitized or replaced at regular intervals as determined by the attending veterinarian in accordance with
generally accepted professional and husbandry practices.
To be corrected by April 1, 2025.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
In the indoor portions of the squirrel monkey enclosures, there is an excessive accumulation of rodent droppings present
on the floor. The facility stated that it is difficult to keep rodents out of the squirrel monkey shed during the winter. There is
evidence that the facility has patched holes in the shed; however, the current pest control program is not effective in this
area.
Pests such as rodents can spread disease and contaminate food, surfaces, and animal housing areas. An effective
program for control of insects, external parasites affecting nonhuman primates, and birds and mammals that are pests,
must be established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination
by pests in animal areas.
To be corrected by April 1, 2025.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, a written environment enhancement plan has not been established to promote the psychological
wellbeing of the birds.
Failure to establish and maintain a plan for environment enhancement can result in the behavioral, social, and
psychological needs of the birds not being met. The plan must address at a minimum social grouping, environment
enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and any birds that are exempted by the attending veterinarian
because of health issues or other conditions. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The facility must
establish and maintain an environment enhancement plan for the birds.
To be corrected by April 18, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.75(c)(3) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There is an accumulation of old food waste stuck in the wire mesh at the front of the owl monkey enclosures. These 
enclosures also have a build up a dark brown material on the perches and food stations. 
Not maintaining appropriate levels of cleanliness in areas where non-human primates come in contact can result in an 
excessive build-up of materials, which can increase the disease risk for the animals contained within. Per the regulations, 
hard surfaces with which nonhuman primates come in contact must be spot-cleaned daily and sanitized in accordance 
with § 3.84 of this subpart to prevent accumulation of excreta or disease hazards. If the species scent mark, the surfaces 
must be sanitized or replaced at regular intervals as determined by the attending veterinarian in accordance with 
generally accepted professional and husbandry practices. 
To be corrected by April 1, 2025. 
3.84(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
In the indoor portions of the squirrel monkey enclosures, there is an excessive accumulation of rodent droppings present 
on the floor. The facility stated that it is difficult to keep rodents out of the squirrel monkey shed during the winter. There is 
evidence that the facility has patched holes in the shed; however, the current pest control program is not effective in this 
area. 
Pests such as rodents can spread disease and contaminate food, surfaces, and animal housing areas. An effective 
program for control of insects, external parasites affecting nonhuman primates, and birds and mammals that are pests, 
must be established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination 
by pests in animal areas. 
To be corrected by April 1, 2025. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
At the time of inspection, a written environment enhancement plan has not been established to promote the psychological 
wellbeing of the birds.  
Failure to establish and maintain a plan for environment enhancement can result in the behavioral, social, and 
psychological needs of the birds not being met. The plan must address at a minimum social grouping, environment

enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and any birds that are exempted by the attending veterinarian 
because of health issues or other conditions. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The facility must 
establish and maintain an environment enhancement plan for the birds.  
To be corrected by April 18, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
